title: Canaries tourist cap proposed to fight 'Magaluf effect'
text:
Canaries tourist cap proposed to fight 'Magaluf effect' 15 July 2015 Save 
Tourist numbers to the Canary Islands could soon be capped in a bid to beat the “Magaluf effect”, the territory’s new president has warned. 
Speaking to The Times, Fernando Clavijo said the destination needs to move away from mass tourism and suggested halting the rising number of all-inclusive properties on the islands. 
He said: “The pursuit of the largest number of tourists is killing quality in Spain. It is the Magaluf effect. 
“Lots of people come from Britiain and what they need is a quality resort. We don’t want to attract 20 million tourists each year and then they do not have a good time. We may need limits.” 
The comments were backed by head of tourism in Las Palmas in Gran Canaria Pedro Quevedo, who added: “We should limit the growth of the industry, ban building on some areas and protect the environment.” 
Fernando Fraile, president of the tourism authority in Tenerife, said: “it is time to think of the quality of tourism we are offering.” 
The paper added of the 11 million tourists that visited the Canaries in 2014, four million were British, making the UK the largest single market.
